com.github.jonathanxd.iutils.opt

Interface Opt<O extends Opt<O,V>,V extends ValueHolder>

  • Type Parameters:
    O - Type of this Opt. Implementations must only pass the same class type to this parameter.
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractOpt, AbstractOptObject, OptBoolean, OptByte, OptChar, OptDouble, OptFloat, OptInt, OptLazy, OptLong, OptObject, OptShort

    public interface Opt<O extends Opt<O,V>,V extends ValueHolder>
    Improved Optional utility. Opt has an specialized version for each primitive type (excluding void type) and is intended to NEVER return null, Java Optional supports null when using Optional.orElse(Object) or Optional.orElseGet(Supplier) and does support Lazy evaluated values. This Optional class also uses a concept of that when you have a value, you have Some value, when you do not have a value, you have None. All classes are built with this concept in mind. All Opt specialized classes extends AbstractOpt and holds a ValueHolder, a ValueHolder is a value-based class that have specialized versions for primitive, object and Lazy types. There are two types of ValueHolders, None and Some (each specialized holder have a implementation for both types). ValueHolders are only like boxed values and does not provide any operation. This class is named Opt to avoid confusion with Option utility.

      • $or

        default Opt<O,V> $or(java.util.function.Supplier<? extends Opt<O,V>> supplier)
        Returns this Opt if value is present, or returns Opt supplied by supplier if not. Returns Opt instead of O (useful in some cases where types are partially erased).
        Parameters:
        supplier - Supplier of other Opt
        Returns:
        This Opt if value is present, or returns Opt supplied by supplier if not.

      • isPresent

        default boolean isPresent()

      • cast

        default O cast()
        Casts this Opt to O. As the documentation says, all implementation of Opt must only provide a O of the same implementing type.
        Returns:
        O instance.

        java.lang.Object getObjectValue()
        Gets object value. Note Boxing should be made in the method implementation and not cached.
